function_call.name: classify_risks_framework
function_call.arguments: {"sorted_risks":[{"name":"Tourism leading to negative environmental and social costs","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"General anxiety leading to low-risk vacation choices","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Limited geographical scope may limit generalizability of findings to other populations.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Limited number of behaviors studied in relation to covid-19 and travel anxiety.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Need for effective approaches to reduce travel-related risk perception and anxiety due to covid-19 and similar health risk situations.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Conflict of interest declaration is missing","category":"Society","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Homogeneous mixing conditions g=1 leading to increased disease spreading","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Variability in contact rates based on age, sex, employment status, and other characteristics","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Crowding driven by urbanization and mobility patterns increasing the growth-rate and size of infectious outbreaks","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Using spatially-resolved census data to infer transportation patterns in cities for urban health simulations","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Characterizing the role of urban design in disease spread using a specific metropolitan area as an example","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Running simulations in hypothetical cities to demonstrate the impact of spatial distributions of housing, education, and economic activities on epidemics","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Inferred mobility patterns based on high-resolution maps of residential density","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Model parameters capturing the effects of transportation infrastructure","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Calculation of trip attraction strength tas based on education and economic activities","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Integration of mobility patterns into epidemiological transmission models","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Inaccurate representation of healthcare facility utilization by sick individuals","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Assumption of fixed daily visits to locations and healthcare facilities","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Segregation of population under sir transmission scheme","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Heterogeneous contact networks through which diseases are spread","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Expected number of si contacts occurring at specific locations","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Calculating the reproductive number in the context of disease transmission","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Interaction between susceptible subgroup and infectives with age-specific transmission potential","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Linear relationship between contact rates and visitor density","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Spatial variations in the basic reproduction number r0","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Increased contact rates in downtown residents led to 50% more efficient spread of pathogens","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Wave-like patterns of disease spread emanating from city center","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Statistical dependence of disease spread on distance from city’s largest retail hub","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Relocating businesses, schools, and housing across cities with unique transportation networks may impact the growth rate and evolution of epidemics.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Inaccurate prediction of attack rates compared to observed data","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Unequal roles of individuals in disease spreading based on location","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Variability in efficiency of vaccination campaigns based on location","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Inequalities in health impacts across different neighborhoods due to remote influence of people in other neighborhoods and characteristics of places where interactions occur.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Assumption of homogeneous mixing in metropolitan areas can bias model results and lead to inaccurate epidemic size predictions.","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Limited representation of non-residential processes in disease transmission models may impact the accuracy of environmental health impact assessments.","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Potential for rapid transmission of pathogens across distant neighborhoods due to uneven distribution of activity hubs in a city.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Lack of isolation of the effects of spatial heterogeneity from all other information embedded in massive mobility datasets used as model input.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Centralization of daily activities in hyper-affluent areas leading to potential interaction among people from all parts of the city.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Uneven distributions of daily activities can lead to segregated subsets of the population, increasing the growth rate of infectious outbreaks.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Centralization of daily activities can result in higher r0 for urban epidemics, leading to increased spread of contagious diseases.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Lack of effect on children’s r0 due to the breakup of activity hubs, potentially leading to targeted spread of contagious diseases among children.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Inaccurate mobility parameters due to lack of real origin-destination data","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Limited accessibility of massive mobility datasets","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Lack of consideration for asymptomatic periods in disease spread modeling","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Neglect of reactive behavior in disease spread modeling","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Inadequate consideration of time-varying mobility matrices in disease spread analysis","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Lack of mobility and contact data for infants and children at different educational stages","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Unaccounted variations in mobility parameters for infected individuals","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Inconsistencies in defining and mapping variables within the numerical grid","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"The spread of infectious disease through the built environment","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"}]}
